awd_titl_txt: REU Site: BU-PRO: Boston University Physics Research Opportunities
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Boston University.  The site will support eight undergraduate students per summer for ten weeks of research in various topics in physics.  The program aims to give students at a critical point in their education meaningful research experiences grounded in physics but with strong links to other physical sciences, including electrical, mechanical, and computer engineering, materials science, and chemistry. The specific components will include 1) research experience working in groups with peers and senior scientists on specific projects; 2) instruction in the culture, methods, and ethics of scientific research; and 3) preparation for a future career in which they will be interacting with colleagues coming from a wide range of backgrounds: intellectual, educational, geographical and cultural. In addition, the program will be linked to BU's internal Undergraduate Research Opportunities (UROP) program so that the REU students will be members of a larger community of student researchers.

The core of the participants' experience will be mentored research within individual research groups. The groups' interests span the range of research in academic physics: from particle physics to biophysics to condensed matter and materials physics to optical physics and photonics. The faculty leading these individual research groups are distinguished scholars at various stages of their careers but all have experience mentoring undergraduates. Carefully structured plenary activities will complement the individual research experiences and provide the students with an understanding of the need for teamwork and interdisciplinary awareness in their future careers.  This award is funded through The Division of Physics and the Division of Materials Research in NSF's Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Scientific and technological development are collective enterprises that rely on diversity of thought and effective collaboration. In the interest of the advancement of science and society, we have a responsibility to train a diverse group of students to enter STEM careers as well as a responsibility to prepare students to interact and collaborate with colleagues from a wide range of backgrounds. At the same time, students must master an intellectually demanding curriculum while also learning practical aspects of computation, data analysis, experimental design, and instrumentation. This REU program addresses these challenges by offering a diverse group of students at a critical point in their education the tools they need to build successful careers in the physical sciences.  In the three years of our program, we hosted 27 student researchers from other institutions and had 7 BU peer ambassadors. The educational trajectories of our non-BU student summer researchers are:

  • 15% of our participants came directly from community colleges.
  • 48% of our participants came from community colleges or four-year colleges.
  • 11% of our participants came from universities that are not classified as research universities in the Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education. 
  • 26% came from schools designated as minority-serving institutions (from all categories).

The core of the BU-PRO participants? experience is mentored research within individual research groups. The faculty mentors who guide students? research and technical training represent a broad range of disciplinary approaches and of academic interests in physics and related fields. Moreover, we have also built in multi-layered mentoring networks and professional and career development opportunities. Outside of the lab, carefully structured plenary activities complement the individual research experiences. Weekly classes offer further opportunities for skill development. All students take a class in Python programming using Jupyter notebooks. The examples, which are designed to teach them broadly applicable computational techniques, are drawn from physics they have already learned.

In exit surveys we performed among the participants written responses included comments such as ?The mentorship I received from my professor was excellent?,? ?This REU program honestly exceeded my expectations,? ??the unconditional support I received from my lab has encouraged me to continue pursuing my STEM degree,? ?The REU program blew away my expectations. My postdoc and Professor were very much available to me at all times,? ?I learned so much in 10 weeks.,? ?It went above my expectations- I learned a lot of technical skills such as coding in R and LaTeX,? ?I learn[ed] to carefully dissect each part of a theoretical procedure in order to construct a clearer research picture,? ?[My mentor?s] genuine curiosity towards me as an underrepresented minority (LatinX and LGTBQ+) made me feel safe from the beginning. She is one of the reasons I will be pursuing graduate school.? Additionally, our surveys asked students what skills they developed in the program. The skills identified by the students were: Teamwork, Time management, Communication (including asking for help, and oral and written communication of scientific findings), Problem Solving and Analytical Skills, Programming and other Computing Skills, Engineering Skills, Self-Advocacy, and Resourcefulness (including learning how to search for and read scientific material). The common theme from the comments is that the BU-PRO REU experience was enjoyable and positive. Students are learning a variety of skills in the program, relevant for both technical and professional development.

One of our participants won the American Physical Society 2021 LeRoy Apker Award for Undergraduate Research, based in part on her REU work and another participant won the inaugural Society of Physics Students Future Teacher Award. Moreover, the 34 students who have participated in our program have been extremely successful in continuing their careers in STEM and education. All of our participants have either completed their bachelor?s degrees, transferred to 4-year institutions, or are on track to graduate. Students have chosen a variety of STEM careers: PhD programs in Physics or related fields (8), Master?s in Education (1), K-12 STEM education (2), and Research & Industry (3).
